questions.text: The rate of absorption of sugars by small intestine is highest for-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Hexoses The rate of absorption of sugars by the small intestine is highest for hexoses (six-carbon sugars like glucose, galactose, and fructose). These monosaccharides are directly absorbed by the enterocytes (intestinal cells) through active and facilitated transport mechanisms. Transport proteins like SGLT1 (for glucose and galactose) and GLUT5 (for fructose) in the intestinal cells facilitate the rapid uptake of these sugars into the bloodstream, making hexoses the fastest absorbed sugars. Incorrect Responses: (A) Disaccharides Disaccharides, like sucrose and lactose, must first be broken down into monosaccharides (like glucose and fructose) by enzymes (such as sucrase and lactase) before they can be absorbed. This additional step of enzymatic digestion slows down the absorption compared to hexoses, so their absorption rate is slower than that of monosaccharides. (B) Polysaccharides Polysaccharides like starch must also undergo breakdown into smaller units (monosaccharides or disaccharides) by enzymes such as amylase before they can be absorbed. The process of digestion and breakdown of polysaccharides takes longer than the absorption of pre-formed monosaccharides, resulting in slower absorption compared to hexoses. (D) Pentose Pentose sugars (five-carbon sugars like ribose and xylose) are not as efficiently absorbed as hexoses in the small intestine. They are absorbed less rapidly due to less efficient transport mechanisms compared to the hexoses, making this option incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is not secreted by the pancreas-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Pepsinogen Pepsinogen is not secreted by the pancreas. It is an inactive precursor of the enzyme pepsin, which is secreted by the chief cells of the stomach lining. Pepsinogen is activated into pepsin in the acidic environment of the stomach, where it plays a role in protein digestion. Since the pancreas does not produce pepsinogen, this is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Procarboxypeptidase The pancreas secretes procarboxypeptidase, an inactive enzyme precursor (zymogen) that is involved in the breakdown of proteins. It is activated into carboxypeptidase in the small intestine, where it aids in the digestion of peptides. Therefore, this option is incorrect as procarboxypeptidase is indeed secreted by the pancreas. (B) Trypsinogen Trypsinogen is also secreted by the pancreas as an inactive precursor. Once it reaches the small intestine, it is activated by enterokinase into the active enzyme trypsin, which helps break down proteins into smaller peptides. Thus, this option is incorrect since trypsinogen is secreted by the pancreas. (C) Phospholipase A The pancreas secretes phospholipase A, an enzyme that plays a role in the digestion of phospholipids, a component of cell membranes. Phospholipase A helps break down phospholipids into fatty acids and other lipid components. Therefore, this option is incorrect, as phospholipase A is secreted by the pancreas.

questions.text: Liver does not produce-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Gamma globulin The liver does not produce gamma globulins. Gamma globulins, also known as immunoglobulins (antibodies), are produced by plasma cells (a type of white blood cell) in response to an immune stimulus. The liver, however, does produce other plasma proteins, but not gamma globulins. Therefore, this is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Albumin The liver produces albumin, which is the most abundant protein in the blood plasma. Albumin plays a key role in maintaining blood volume and osmotic pressure, and it also binds to various substances in the blood. Therefore, this option is incorrect, as albumin is produced by the liver. (C) Fibrinogen The liver also produces fibrinogen, a clotting factor that is essential for blood coagulation. It is converted into fibrin during the clotting process to help form blood clots. Hence, this option is incorrect because fibrinogen is produced by the liver. (D) Prothrombin Prothrombin is another clotting factor produced by the liver. It is converted into thrombin during the clotting cascade, which plays a crucial role in blood coagulation. Therefore, this option is incorrect as prothrombin is produced by the liver.

questions.text: Gastrin secretion by Pyloric antrum is stimulated by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above The secretion of gastrin by the pyloric antrum is stimulated by a combination of factors, all of which are correct: Peptides and amino acids: When proteins are present in the stomach, peptides and amino acids stimulate gastrin secretion. These substances act as a signal for the body to release gastrin, which in turn stimulates gastric acid secretion to aid in digestion. Increased vagal discharge via GRP (Gastrin-Releasing Peptide): The vagus nerve releases GRP during parasympathetic stimulation, which directly stimulates the pyloric antrum to secrete gastrin. This response is enhanced during the cephalic phase of digestion when the body anticipates food. Distension of the antrum: When the stomach is stretched due to the presence of food, it triggers mechanoreceptors in the gastric mucosa, leading to the release of gastrin. All these factors work together to stimulate gastrin secretion from the pyloric antrum, making D the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Peptides and amino acids While peptides and amino acids do stimulate gastrin secretion, this option does not account for all the factors involved in the process. Therefore, it is incomplete by itself, making it an incorrect response. (B) Increased vagal discharge via GRP Increased vagal discharge via GRP does indeed stimulate gastrin secretion, but this option also does not consider other stimuli such as peptides, amino acids, and distension of the antrum. Therefore, it is also incorrect on its own. (C) Distension of antrum Distension of the antrum is a valid stimulus for gastrin secretion, but like the previous options, it does not include the other key factors such as peptides, amino acids, and vagal discharge via GRP, which together constitute the full picture of gastrin secretion regulation. Hence, it is incorrect without the other factors.

questions.text: Following are gastrointestinal hormones except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Chymotrypsin Chymotrypsin is an enzyme secreted by the pancreas involved in protein digestion, not a gastrointestinal hormone. Unlike gastrointestinal hormones, enzymes like chymotrypsin facilitate digestion by breaking down proteins in the small intestine. Therefore, D is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) CCK-PZ (Cholecystokinin) CCK-PZ (or cholecystokinin) is a gastrointestinal hormone secreted by the duodenum and jejunum. It stimulates the release of bile from the gallbladder and pancreatic enzymes, as well as inhibits gastric emptying. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) GIP (Gastric Inhibitory Peptide) GIP is a gastrointestinal hormone secreted by the K cells of the duodenum and jejunum. It inhibits gastric acid secretion and slows gastric emptying. Additionally, it stimulates insulin secretion in response to glucose and fat intake. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) Motilin Motilin is a gastrointestinal hormone secreted by the small intestine, specifically during fasting. It regulates motility by stimulating the migrating motor complex, which helps clear the stomach and small intestine of undigested material. Therefore, C is incorrect.

questions.text: All of the following are required for digestion of dietary fat except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bile pigments Bile pigments are byproducts of the breakdown of hemoglobin and include substances such as bilirubin. These pigments are not involved in the digestion of dietary fats. The primary role of bile pigments is to be excreted in the bile and eliminated from the body, but they do not play a direct role in fat digestion. Therefore, A is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (B) Colipase Colipase is a protein coenzyme that is required for the optimal functioning of pancreatic lipase. It helps anchor lipase to the surface of fat droplets in the intestine, facilitating the digestion of dietary fats. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) Bile salts Bile salts are crucial for the digestion of fats. They emulsify large fat droplets into smaller ones, increasing the surface area for lipase action. This emulsification is necessary for efficient fat digestion and absorption in the small intestine. Therefore, C is incorrect. (D) Pancreatic lipase Pancreatic lipase is the primary enzyme responsible for breaking down triglycerides into free fatty acids and monoglycerides. It works in conjunction with bile salts and colipase to digest dietary fats in the small intestine. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the primary site of production of gastrin-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Antrum Gastrin is primarily produced in the antrum of the stomach, specifically by G cells located in this region. Gastrin secretion is stimulated by the presence of food in the stomach and promotes the secretion of gastric acid, aiding in digestion. Therefore, B is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Pylorus The pylorus is the region of the stomach that connects to the duodenum. While it plays a role in regulating the flow of stomach contents into the small intestine, it is not the primary site for the production of gastrin. Therefore, A is incorrect. (C) Pancreas The pancreas is involved in producing digestive enzymes and bicarbonate but does not produce gastrin. Gastrin is produced specifically in the stomach, not the pancreas. Therefore, C is incorrect. (D) Small intestine The small intestine does play a role in the digestive process, and some hormones like secretin and cholecystokinin (CCK) are produced here, but gastrin is not. Gastrin is mainly produced in the stomach, particularly in the antrum. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: Intrinsic factor is secreted by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Parietal or Oxyntic cells Intrinsic factor is secreted by the parietal cells (also called oxyntic cells) in the stomach lining. This glycoprotein is crucial for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the small intestine. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot be effectively absorbed, leading to deficiencies. Therefore, C is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) G-cells G-cells in the stomach are responsible for secreting gastrin, a hormone that stimulates acid secretion and gastric motility. However, G-cells do not secrete intrinsic factor. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) Pepsinogen secreting cells Pepsinogen is secreted by chief cells (also known as peptic cells) in the stomach. Pepsinogen is the inactive precursor of pepsin, an enzyme that helps digest proteins. These cells do not secrete intrinsic factor. Therefore, B is incorrect. (D) Pyloric glands The pyloric glands are located in the pyloric region of the stomach and primarily secrete gastrin from G-cells, as well as mucus to protect the stomach lining. They do not produce intrinsic factor. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: Salivary amylase is activated by-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cl- Salivary amylase, an enzyme responsible for the breakdown of starches into sugars, is activated by chloride ions (Cl-). Chloride ions are essential for the optimal activity of salivary amylase, as they help in maintaining its structure and function. Without chloride, the enzyme's activity is reduced. Therefore, D is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Na+ Sodium ions (Na+) are involved in the general functioning of the body and are important in maintaining osmotic balance and fluid distribution, but they do not directly activate salivary amylase. Therefore, A is incorrect. (B) K+ Potassium ions (K+ ) play a critical role in nerve and muscle function but do not activate salivary amylase. The enzyme’s activity is not specifically enhanced by potassium. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) HCO3- Bicarbonate ions (HCO3-) help to neutralize the acidic environment in the mouth and maintain the optimal pH for salivary amylase function, but they do not directly activate the enzyme. The enzyme activation requires chloride ions. Therefore, C is incorrect.

questions.text: In the stomach, H+ ions are secreted in exchange for –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) K+ In the stomach, H+ ions (protons) are secreted by parietal cells through a proton-potassium pump, also known as the H+/K+ ATPase. This pump exchanges H+ ions for K+ ions. For every proton secreted into the lumen of the stomach, a potassium ion is brought back into the parietal cell. This process helps maintain the highly acidic environment required for digestion. Therefore, B is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Na+ Sodium ions (Na+) are not involved in the direct exchange with protons in the stomach. While sodium does play a role in other cellular processes (e.g., maintaining osmotic balance), it is not exchanged with H+ in the stomach's proton pump mechanism. Therefore, A is incorrect. (C) Ca+ Calcium ions (Ca+) are not directly involved in the exchange with protons in the stomach. Calcium plays a role in various cellular signaling pathways, but it does not directly exchange with hydrogen ions for acid secretion in the stomach. Therefore, C is incorrect. (D) Cl- Chloride ions (Cl-) are not exchanged directly for H+ ions. Instead, chloride ions are secreted alongside hydrogen ions into the stomach lumen, where they combine to form hydrochloric acid (HCl). However, chloride is not exchanged for hydrogen in the same manner as potassium is in the H+/K+ ATPase pump. Therefore, D is incorrect.

questions.text: All are endo peptidases except-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Carboxypeptidases Carboxypeptidases are exo-peptidases, not endo-peptidases. Exo-peptidases cleave amino acids from the carboxyl end of peptides, releasing individual amino acids. Unlike endo-peptidases, which cleave peptide bonds within the protein chain, carboxypeptidases specifically target the end of the peptide chain. Therefore, D is the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (A) Trypsin Trypsin is an endo-peptidase, meaning it breaks peptide bonds within the protein chain. Trypsin specifically cleaves peptide bonds after lysine or arginine residues. Thus, A is incorrect. (B) Chymotrypsin Chymotrypsin is also an endo-peptidase. It cleaves peptide bonds at the aromatic amino acids such as phenylalanine, tyrosine, and tryptophan. Thus, B is incorrect. (C) Elastase Elastase is another endo-peptidase. It breaks down elastin and other proteins by cleaving peptide bonds within the chain. It is classified as an endo-peptidase, so C is incorrect.

questions.text: Maximum potassium ions secretion is seen in –
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Saliva The maximum secretion of potassium ions occurs in saliva. The salivary glands, particularly the parotid glands, secrete saliva that contains a high concentration of potassium ions. This is due to the active transport of potassium ions into the saliva, especially under conditions of stimulation, making A the correct answer. Incorrect Responses: (B) Gastric secretions While gastric secretions do contain potassium, the amount is much less than in saliva. Gastric acid primarily consists of hydrochloric acid (HCl), and although some potassium is secreted, it is not the dominant ion. Therefore, B is incorrect. (C) Jejunal secretions The jejunal secretions, produced by the small intestine, contain bicarbonate ions and enzymes, but the potassium concentration is not as high as in saliva. Therefore, C is incorrect. (D) Colonic secretions In the colon, potassium is absorbed rather than secreted in large amounts. Although there is some potassium secretion in the colon, it is much less compared to the secretion in saliva. Therefore, D is also incorrect.

questions.text: Cephalic phase of gastric secretion is mediated by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Parasympathetic nervous system The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is primarily mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system. This phase is triggered by sensory stimuli such as the sight, smell, or taste of food, which activates the vagus nerve. The vagus nerve stimulates the parietal cells in the stomach to secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl), and also promotes the release of other gastric secretions like pepsinogen, preparing the stomach for food intake. Incorrect Responses: (A) Neurohormones While neurohormones can influence gastric secretion, they are not the primary mediators of the cephalic phase. The cephalic phase is predominantly controlled by neural mechanisms, specifically the parasympathetic nervous system via the vagus nerve, rather than by neurohormones. (C) Sympathetic nervous system The sympathetic nervous system typically has an inhibitory effect on gastric secretion. While it may have some indirect influence on gastric activity, it does not play a primary role in the cephalic phase, which is more closely associated with the parasympathetic system. (D) Gastrin While gastrin is an important hormone for stimulating gastric acid secretion, it is not the primary mediator during the cephalic phase. Gastrin is primarily released during the gastric phase when food enters the stomach, not in response to sensory stimuli like in the cephalic phase. The cephalic phase is predominantly driven by neural inputs, particularly from the parasympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: Most potent stimulus for secretin is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Acidic chyme The most potent stimulus for the secretion of secretin is the presence of acidic chyme in the duodenum. When the acidic contents from the stomach enter the duodenum, they stimulate the release of secretin from S cells in the duodenal mucosa. Secretin helps regulate the pH of the intestine by stimulating the pancreas to secrete bicarbonate-rich fluid, which neutralizes the acid, thus protecting the intestinal lining and creating an optimal pH for enzyme function. Incorrect Responses: (A) Dilatation of intestine While intestinal distention can stimulate some gastrointestinal hormones, it is not the primary trigger for secretin release. Distention generally activates the mechanoreceptors and can lead to the release of other hormones like gastrin or motilin, but the most potent stimulus for secretin is the presence of acidic chyme, not distention. (C) Protein Proteins do play a role in stimulating various digestive enzymes and hormones, including gastrin, but protein is not a potent stimulus for secretin. The major stimulus for secretin is the acidic nature of the chyme, not the protein content. (D) Fat While fat can influence gastric and pancreatic secretions, fat is not the most potent stimulus for secretin. Fatty acids in the chyme stimulate the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which helps in the digestion of fat, but the key trigger for secretin release is the acidity of the chyme.

questions.text: Best stimuli for CCK secretion is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) (Ref. Ganong’s Physiology 25th edition, page 470). Explanation- The secretion of CCK is increased by contact of the intes¬tinal mucosa with the products of digestion, particularly peptides and amino acids, and also by the presence in the duo-denum of fatty acids containing more than 10 carbon atoms. There are also two protein releasing factors that activate CCK secretion, known as CCK-releasing peptide and monitor pep¬tide, which derive from the intestinal mucosa and pancreas, respectively.

questions.text: Pepsinogen is activated by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Low pH Pepsinogen is an inactive precursor (zymogen) of the enzyme pepsin. It is activated by the acidic environment of the stomach, specifically by a low pH. When the pH of the stomach becomes sufficiently acidic (below 3), pepsinogen undergoes a conformational change, converting into the active enzyme pepsin. Pepsin is essential for breaking down proteins into smaller peptides during digestion. Incorrect Responses: (A) Enterokinase Enterokinase (also known as enteropeptidase) is involved in the activation of trypsinogen to trypsin in the small intestine, but it does not activate pepsinogen. Enterokinase is not involved in pepsinogen activation, which occurs specifically due to the acidic environment of the stomach. (C) Trypsin Trypsin is involved in the activation of other zymogens, such as chymotrypsinogen and procarboxypeptidase, in the small intestine, but it does not play a role in activating pepsinogen. Pepsinogen activation is specifically triggered by a low pH in the stomach. (D) Chymotrypsin Similar to trypsin, chymotrypsin activates other digestive enzymes in the small intestine, but it does not activate pepsinogen. Chymotrypsin is not involved in the activation of pepsinogen; that process is strictly regulated by the acidic environment in the stomach.

questions.text: Secretion of bile into bile canaliculus is by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Active transport across the membrane The secretion of bile into the bile canaliculus occurs through active transport mechanisms. Hepatocytes, the liver cells, actively transport bile components such as bile acids, bilirubin, cholesterol, and phospholipids into the bile canaliculus. This active transport requires ATP and involves specific transport proteins located in the hepatocyte's canalicular membrane, such as BSEP (bile salt export pump) for bile salts and MDR3 (multidrug resistance protein) for phospholipids. Active transport ensures that bile is efficiently secreted against concentration gradients, facilitating the proper functioning of the digestive system. Incorrect Responses: (A) Osmotic gradient An osmotic gradient is involved in the movement of water in various physiological processes, but bile secretion is not driven by an osmotic gradient. Although water is secreted into bile, the primary mechanism for bile secretion is active transport, not osmosis. The bile is concentrated as a result of active transport processes that move solutes like bile salts into the canaliculus, with water following by osmosis. (B) Facilitated diffusion Facilitated diffusion is a passive process that allows molecules to move across a membrane down their concentration gradient with the help of carrier proteins. While some substances in bile may enter cells via facilitated diffusion, bile secretion into the bile canaliculus does not occur through facilitated diffusion. Instead, the hepatocyte actively transports bile components into the canaliculus, a process that requires energy. (D) Simple diffusion Simple diffusion refers to the movement of molecules from an area of higher concentration to an area of lower concentration without the need for energy or carrier proteins. While some small molecules may enter hepatocytes via simple diffusion, bile secretion into the bile canaliculus is not a passive process and cannot occur via simple diffusion. Active transport is required to move the bile components against concentration gradients into the canaliculus.

questions.text: Trypsinogen is converted to trypsin by :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Enterokinase Trypsinogen is an inactive precursor (proenzyme) of trypsin and is converted to its active form, trypsin, by the enzyme enterokinase (also called enteropeptidase). Enterokinase is secreted by the cells lining the duodenum. Once trypsinogen enters the duodenum, enterokinase cleaves a specific peptide bond in trypsinogen, activating it to trypsin. The active trypsin then goes on to activate other pancreatic enzymes, including more trypsinogen, in a positive feedback loop. Incorrect Responses: (A) Pepsin Pepsin is an enzyme found in the stomach, and it is responsible for the breakdown of proteins into peptides. It does not play a role in the conversion of trypsinogen to trypsin. Pepsin is involved in protein digestion in the acidic environment of the stomach, whereas the conversion of trypsinogen to trypsin occurs in the small intestine by enterokinase. (C) HCl Hydrochloric acid (HCl) is secreted in the stomach and is responsible for maintaining the acidic environment, which activates pepsinogen to pepsin for protein digestion. However, HCl does not activate trypsinogen. Trypsinogen activation occurs specifically through the action of enterokinase in the small intestine. (D) None This option is incorrect because enterokinase is the enzyme responsible for converting trypsinogen into trypsin. Therefore, stating that "none" is responsible for this conversion is inaccurate.

questions.text: Resection of which intestinal segment causes marked electrolyte imbalance :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Jejunum The jejunum plays a significant role in the absorption of nutrients, including electrolytes such as sodium, potassium, and chloride. The jejunum is also where most of the absorption of water, proteins, and carbohydrates occurs. When the jejunum is resected, it significantly impacts the absorption capacity of the small intestine, leading to marked electrolyte imbalances and dehydration. This is because it decreases the area available for electrolyte absorption and disrupts the osmotic balance. Incorrect Responses: (A) Duodenum The duodenum is responsible for the initial digestion and neutralization of stomach acids, as well as absorption of some nutrients. While resection of the duodenum can lead to some nutritional deficiencies, it does not cause as marked an electrolyte imbalance as resection of the jejunum. The primary function of the duodenum is not the absorption of large quantities of electrolytes, making its resection less impactful in terms of electrolyte balance. (C) Ileum The ileum is primarily responsible for the absorption of vitamin B12 and bile salts, as well as some electrolytes. While ileal resection can cause issues like B12 deficiency or problems with bile salt recycling, it does not typically result in the same degree of electrolyte imbalance seen with resection of the jejunum. The ileum still has some capacity for electrolyte absorption, but its resection is less likely to cause severe electrolyte disturbances compared to the jejunum. (D) Sigmoid The sigmoid colon is involved in water and electrolyte reabsorption, particularly during the process of forming stool. However, its resection does not typically cause significant electrolyte imbalances because the large intestine plays a secondary role in nutrient absorption compared to the small intestine. The major impact of sigmoid resection would be related to stool formation and possible changes in bowel movements, but not as much to electrolyte balance.

questions.text: Cephalic phase of gastric secretion:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) 20% The cephalic phase of gastric secretion is the initial phase triggered by the sight, smell, or thought of food. It accounts for about 20% of the total gastric secretions. This phase is mediated by the parasympathetic nervous system, specifically through the vagus nerve, which stimulates the secretion of gastric juices even before food enters the stomach. The cephalic phase prepares the stomach for digestion by increasing gastric acid and enzyme secretion. Incorrect Responses: (B) 70% While the cephalic phase is an important part of gastric secretion, it only accounts for about 20% of the total gastric secretion. The majority of gastric secretions come from the gastric phase, which occurs after food enters the stomach. In the gastric phase, the presence of food in the stomach triggers more significant secretion of gastric acid and digestive enzymes. (C) 10% The cephalic phase is responsible for about 20% of gastric secretion, not just 10%. While this percentage may seem relatively low compared to the gastric phase, it is still significant in preparing the digestive system for food intake. (D) 100% The cephalic phase contributes only a portion of the total gastric secretion, about 20%. The remaining secretion occurs during the gastric phase and the intestinal phase, with the gastric phase contributing the largest portion. Therefore, 100% of gastric secretion is not solely attributed to the cephalic phase.

questions.text: Which vitamins are synthesized by intestinal bacteria:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Vitamin K and B Intestinal bacteria play an important role in synthesizing certain vitamins that are vital for human health. Vitamin K and several B vitamins, including B12, B2 (riboflavin), and B7 (biotin), are synthesized by the microbiota in the gut, particularly in the colon. These vitamins are absorbed by the host and contribute to essential functions, such as blood clotting (for Vitamin K) and energy metabolism (for B vitamins). Vitamin K, for example, is crucial for the synthesis of clotting factors, while B vitamins are involved in processes like DNA synthesis and the metabolism of carbohydrates, fats, and proteins. Incorrect Responses: (A) Vitamin K and D Although Vitamin K is synthesized by intestinal bacteria, Vitamin D is not. Vitamin D is primarily synthesized in the skin through a chemical reaction triggered by exposure to sunlight, specifically UVB rays. While some dietary sources of Vitamin D are absorbed in the intestines, it is not produced by intestinal bacteria. (C) Vitamin A and D Vitamin A and Vitamin D are not synthesized by intestinal bacteria. Vitamin A is obtained from dietary sources, including retinol and carotenoids, while Vitamin D is synthesized by the skin in response to sunlight, as mentioned earlier. Neither of these vitamins is produced by gut bacteria. (D) Vitamin K and C Vitamin C is not synthesized by intestinal bacteria. Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, must be obtained through the diet, primarily from fruits and vegetables. Intestinal bacteria are involved in the synthesis of Vitamin K, but not Vitamin C.

questions.text: Gastric secretion in increased by all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) HCl Hydrochloric acid (HCl) in the stomach does not directly increase gastric secretion. In fact, HCl is a product of gastric secretion, specifically secreted by parietal cells in the stomach. The presence of HCl provides an acidic environment necessary for the activation of pepsinogen to pepsin and for the digestion of food, but it does not directly stimulate further gastric secretion. Instead, the secretion of HCl itself is regulated by other factors such as histamine, acetylcholine, and gastrin, which stimulate the parietal cells to produce more HCl. Incorrect Responses: (A) Histamine Histamine is one of the key stimulators of gastric secretion. It acts on the H2 receptors of parietal cells in the stomach, leading to the secretion of HCl. Histamine plays a significant role in amplifying the effects of other gastric stimulants like acetylcholine and gastrin. (B) Acetylcholine Acetylcholine is another important neurotransmitter that stimulates gastric secretion. It acts through the muscarinic receptors on parietal cells, promoting the release of HCl. It also stimulates the release of pepsinogen from chief cells and enhances the motility of the stomach, contributing to the overall digestive process. (C) Gastrin Gastrin is a hormone produced by the G cells in the antrum of the stomach. It is a potent stimulant for gastric acid secretion. Gastrin acts on cholecystokinin (CCK) receptors on the parietal cells and stimulates the production of HCl. Additionally, gastrin promotes the secretion of pepsinogen from the chief cells and increases gastric motility. It is one of the most important regulators of gastric secretion.

questions.text: HCI secretion in gastric phase is increased by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Gastrin Gastrin is the primary stimulant for hydrochloric acid (HCl) secretion during the gastric phase. Gastrin is released by G cells in the antrum of the stomach in response to the presence of food. Once released, gastrin stimulates parietal cells to secrete HCl, which is essential for digestion. Gastrin also promotes the secretion of pepsinogen from chief cells and increases gastric motility, all of which help in the digestion of food in the stomach. Incorrect Responses: (A) Pepsinogen Pepsinogen is an inactive precursor of the enzyme pepsin, and it is secreted by chief cells. The secretion of pepsinogen is necessary for the digestion of proteins, but it does not directly stimulate the secretion of HCl. In fact, pepsinogen is activated to pepsin by the acidic environment created by HCl, which helps in protein digestion. (B) CCK (Cholecystokinin) Cholecystokinin is a hormone primarily involved in the digestion of fats and proteins. It is released from the duodenum in response to the presence of fats and proteins in the chyme. CCK stimulates bile secretion from the gallbladder and pancreatic enzyme release. However, CCK does not play a significant role in stimulating HCl secretion during the gastric phase. (D) HCl The secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) is not directly increased by HCl itself. In fact, the presence of HCl in the stomach is regulated by other factors, primarily gastrin, acetylcholine, and histamine. Excess HCl secretion can lead to conditions such as acid reflux or ulcers, but HCl does not act as a stimulant for its own secretion during the gastric phase.

questions.text: I cells in the small intestine secrete:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) CCK (Cholecystokinin) I cells, located in the duodenum and jejunum of the small intestine, secrete cholecystokinin (CCK) in response to the presence of fatty acids and amino acids in the chyme. CCK plays a critical role in digestion by stimulating the gallbladder to release bile and the pancreas to secrete digestive enzymes. Additionally, CCK inhibits gastric emptying to allow sufficient time for nutrient digestion and absorption. Incorrect Responses: (A) Secretin Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum and is released when acidic chyme enters the small intestine. Its primary role is to stimulate the pancreas to release bicarbonate-rich fluid to neutralize the acidity, creating an optimal pH for digestive enzymes. Secretin is not secreted by I cells. (B) Gastrin Gastrin is secreted by G cells in the antrum of the stomach, not by I cells in the small intestine. Gastrin stimulates the secretion of gastric acid (HCl) from parietal cells in the stomach and promotes gastric motility. It does not play a role in the secretion of digestive enzymes in the small intestine like CCK. (D) Motilin Motilin is secreted by M cells in the duodenum and jejunum, and it primarily regulates the migrating motor complex (MMC), which is involved in the clearing of the stomach and small intestine between meals. Motilin does not directly influence digestion by stimulating enzyme or bile release, unlike CCK.

questions.text: Parietal cell secretions are essential for absorption of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cobalamin (Vitamin B12) Parietal cells in the stomach secrete hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor (IF). Intrinsic factor is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12 (cobalamin) in the ileum. Without intrinsic factor, vitamin B12 cannot bind to its receptors in the ileum, leading to impaired absorption and potentially to vitamin B12 deficiency. Incorrect Responses: (B) Fat Fat absorption primarily occurs in the small intestine, particularly in the duodenum and jejunum, through the action of bile acids and pancreatic lipase. While gastric acid aids in fat digestion by emulsifying fats, parietal cell secretions are not directly responsible for fat absorption. (C) Thiamine Thiamine (vitamin B1) is absorbed in the small intestine, mainly in the duodenum and jejunum, but it does not require gastric acid or intrinsic factor for its absorption. Parietal cells do not play a role in thiamine absorption. (D) Protein Protein digestion and absorption occur primarily in the stomach and small intestine. Gastric acid from parietal cells helps to denature proteins and activate pepsinogen into pepsin, which starts the breakdown of proteins. However, absorption of proteins occurs as amino acids or peptides in the small intestine, not directly facilitated by parietal cell secretions.

questions.text: A man cannot digest carbohydrate. The enzyme deficient is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amylase The enzyme amylase is responsible for breaking down carbohydrates into simpler sugars, such as maltose and dextrins, during digestion. It is secreted by the salivary glands (salivary amylase) and the pancreas (pancreatic amylase). If a person cannot digest carbohydrates, it is likely due to a deficiency in amylase, either in the salivary or pancreatic form, which would prevent the breakdown of starches into absorbable sugars. Incorrect Responses: (A) Lipase Lipase is an enzyme responsible for breaking down fats into fatty acids and glycerol. A deficiency in lipase would impair fat digestion, not carbohydrate digestion, so this enzyme is unrelated to the inability to digest carbohydrates. (C) Pepsin Pepsin is an enzyme produced by the stomach that breaks down proteins into smaller peptides. It is not involved in carbohydrate digestion, so a deficiency in pepsin would not affect carbohydrate digestion. (D) Trypsin Trypsin is another protein-digesting enzyme produced by the pancreas. It breaks down proteins into smaller peptides. Like pepsin, it is unrelated to carbohydrate digestion and would not be the enzyme deficient in this case.

questions.text: “Delta cells" of stomach secrete:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Somatostatin The delta cells of the stomach secrete somatostatin, which plays a crucial role in inhibiting gastric secretion. Somatostatin inhibits the release of various gastrointestinal hormones, including gastrin and insulin, and helps regulate digestive processes by decreasing gastric acid secretion, gastric motility, and the release of digestive enzymes. It serves as a negative feedback regulator to prevent excessive secretion during digestion. Incorrect Responses: (A) Cholecystokinin Cholecystokinin (CCK) is not secreted by delta cells of the stomach. CCK is produced by I cells in the small intestine, particularly in the duodenum and jejunum, in response to the presence of fats and proteins. CCK stimulates the gallbladder to release bile and enhances enzyme secretion from the pancreas. (B) Gastrin releasing peptide Gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP) is not secreted by delta cells of the stomach. It is actually released by the vagus nerve and stimulates the G cells of the stomach to release gastrin, which in turn increases gastric acid secretion. GRP is involved in the regulation of gastric acid production but is not secreted by the delta cells. (D) Secretin Secretin is not secreted by delta cells. Secretin is produced by S cells in the duodenum in response to acidic chyme entering from the stomach. It stimulates the pancreas to release bicarbonate, which helps neutralize stomach acid in the small intestine. Secretin plays an essential role in maintaining the pH balance in the digestive system but is not produced by the delta cells of the stomach.

questions.text: Lingual lipase is secreted by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Ebner’s Gland Lingual lipase is primarily secreted by the Ebner's glands, which are located in the circumvallate papillae on the back of the tongue. These glands secrete an enzyme that plays a role in the digestion of lipids, particularly in the infant's digestion of milk fat. Lingual lipase acts on triglycerides to break them down into diglycerides and free fatty acids, especially in the acidic environment of the stomach, where it functions effectively. Incorrect Responses: (A) Parotid Gland The parotid glands are primarily responsible for secreting salivary amylase, not lingual lipase. Amylase begins the digestion of carbohydrates in the mouth. These glands do not contribute significantly to lipase production. (C) Sublingual Glands The sublingual glands are involved in the secretion of mucous and saliva, which lubricate the mouth and help in the initial stages of digestion, but they do not secrete lingual lipase. Their secretions help with the mechanical digestion of food, but the enzyme is not lipase. (D) None This option is incorrect because Ebner’s glands (option B) do secrete lingual lipase, making this choice false.

questions.text: Which of the following is Hydrocholeretic:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Secretin Secretin is a hydrocholeretic agent, meaning it stimulates the secretion of bile by the liver. Secretin is released in response to acidic chyme entering the duodenum, and it promotes the secretion of bicarbonate-rich bile from the liver and pancreas to neutralize the acidity of the chyme. This process is crucial for optimal digestive function in the small intestine. Incorrect Responses: (A) CCK Cholecystokinin (CCK) primarily stimulates the gallbladder contraction to release bile and also promotes enzyme secretion from the pancreas. While it does play a role in bile secretion, it is not primarily hydrocholeretic, as its main effect is on gallbladder contraction rather than direct bile production by the liver. (C) Fatty acids Fatty acids in the duodenum stimulate bile secretion, but their primary role is in stimulating CCK release, which subsequently triggers bile release from the gallbladder. They are not considered hydrocholeretic by themselves, as they act indirectly by promoting CCK release. (D) Amino acids Amino acids can stimulate the release of both CCK and gastrin, which promote enzyme secretion from the pancreas and gastric acid secretion, respectively. However, they do not have a direct hydrocholeretic effect, as they do not stimulate bile secretion by the liver directly.

questions.text: Lowest pH is seen in which of the following gastrointestinal secretion:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gastric juice Gastric juice has the lowest pH among the gastrointestinal secretions, typically ranging from 1.5 to 3.5. The acidic environment is primarily due to the secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) by parietal cells in the stomach. This highly acidic pH is necessary for the activation of pepsinogen to pepsin, an enzyme responsible for protein digestion, and also helps in killing harmful microorganisms in ingested food. Incorrect Responses: (B) Bile juice Bile has a slightly alkaline pH, usually ranging from 7.6 to 8.6. It is secreted by the liver and stored in the gallbladder, and its primary role is to aid in the digestion and absorption of fats. The alkaline nature of bile helps neutralize the acidic chyme from the stomach as it enters the duodenum. (C) Saliva Saliva has a neutral to slightly alkaline pH, typically around 6.5 to 7.5. Its role is to moisten food, begin the digestion of carbohydrates via salivary amylase, and protect the mouth with enzymes that help reduce bacterial growth. The pH of saliva is not as low as gastric juice. (D) Pancreatic juice Pancreatic juice is also alkaline, with a pH typically around 7.8 to 8.4. It is secreted by the pancreas into the duodenum and contains bicarbonate ions, which help neutralize the acidic chyme from the stomach. The alkaline nature aids in creating an optimal environment for the digestive enzymes to function effectively.

questions.text: Daily salivary secretion is :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) 800-1200 ml The daily salivary secretion is typically around 800 to 1200 ml. Saliva is produced by three main salivary glands: the parotid glands, submandibular glands, and sublingual glands. Saliva serves multiple functions, including moistening food for easier swallowing, initiating digestion (through enzymes like amylase), and protecting the mouth from infections and acidity. The volume of saliva produced can vary depending on factors such as hydration, food intake, and overall health. Incorrect Responses: (A) 250-500 ml While this amount is lower than the average daily secretion of saliva, it is still possible in individuals with certain conditions, such as reduced salivation (xerostomia), but it does not reflect typical daily output. This volume would be considered insufficient for normal oral health and digestion. (C) 2000-2500 ml This volume is considerably higher than the typical salivary secretion. While some individuals may have a higher output, this would be an excessive amount of saliva, which could be indicative of a condition like sialorrhea (excessive salivation), often associated with certain neurological disorders or medications. (D) 3000 ml This is also much higher than the usual daily secretion of saliva. A volume of 3000 ml would be unusual and could be related to a pathological condition. In healthy individuals, the production of saliva does not generally reach this level.

questions.text: A new drug is developed that blocksthe transporter for H+ secretion in gastricparietal cells. Which of the followingtransport processes is being inhibited?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Primary active transport. Explanation: In gastric parietal cells, the secretion of hydrogen ions (H+) into the stomach lumen is facilitated by the proton pump, also known as the H+/K+ ATPase. This pump actively transports H+ ions against their concentration gradient into the stomach, a process that requires energy in the form of ATP. Blocking this transporter inhibits the primary active transport mechanism responsible for acidifying the stomach. Incorrect options: A. Simple diffusion: This is a passive transport process where substances move down their concentration gradient without energy expenditure. The secretion of H+ ions by the proton pump is an active process, not passive. B. Facilitated diffusion: This passive transport mechanism involves the movement of substances down their concentration gradient through a carrier protein, without energy input. The proton pump requires ATP, distinguishing it from facilitated diffusion. D. Cotransport: Also known as symport, cotransport involves the simultaneous transport of two substances in the same direction across a membrane, typically utilizing the gradient of one substance to drive the transport of another. The proton pump operates independently of other substances and does not utilize a cotransport mechanism.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the mechanism by which the gastrointestinal system coordinates the process of food digestion. Specifically, she is interested in how distension of the lower esophagus by a bolus of food changes responses in the downstream segments of the digestive system. She observes that there is a resulting relaxation and opening of the lower esophageal (cardiac) sphincter after the introduction of a food bolus. Which of the following substances is most likely involved in the process being observed here?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This scientist who is studying the relationship between a food bolus and smooth muscle relaxation is most likely examining the vagovagal reflex, which is mediated by vasoactive intestinal polypeptide. Receptive relaxation is the process by which distension of the lower esophagus by the food bolus produces relaxation of the smooth muscle in the esophageal sphincter and the proximal stomach. Specifically, the efferent arm of this process involves the central nervous system relaying motor information to the smooth muscle via efferent fibers of the vagus nerve. The postganglionic vagal efferent fibers perform this function by releasing vasoactive intestinal polypeptide.

questions.text: In an experimental model, a compound is centrally administered to rats. Following administration, the rats display increased desire for food and increased appetite. The administered compound is most likely similar to which of the following
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Neuropeptide-Y (NPY) is a peptide hormone that increases hunger. Many peptide hormones are produced in the gastrointestinal tract. In addition to their roles in the digestive process, some of these hormones influence eating behaviors. NPY acts centrally to increase hunger and also acts to decrease energy expenditure. Ghrelin is another peptide hormone which acts to increase hunger. Several hormones, including peptide YY, glucagon-like peptide 1, and cholecystokinin act to signal satiety.

questions.text: A 17-year-old patient suffering from type 1 diabetes is noncompliant with his required insulin therapy and develops hyperglycemia after eating chocolate. The release of which of the following intestinal hormones would most likely be stimulated?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Gastric inhibitory peptide (GIP) is produced in the duodenal and jejunal mucosa by K cells and is released in response to intraluminal glucose and fatty acids. GIP is sometimes called “glucose-dependent insulinotropic” peptide because it stimulates pancreatic insulin secretion in the presence of hyperglycemia. Note that although GIP release would be stimulated, the hormone would not have a pronounced effect in this type 1 diabetic, whose pancreatic islet cells do not produce adequate amounts of insulin. Gastrin is synthesized and stored primarily in the G cells of the stomach and TG cells of the stomach and smallintestine. The stimuli for gastrin secretion include increased vagal discharge, digestive products, calcium salts, and gastric distention. Gastrin stimulates HCl secretion by parietal cells, histamine release from enterochromaffin cells, pepsinogen secretion by chief cells, gastric blood flow, and contraction of gastric circular smooth muscle. It has a trophic effect on gastric and small- intestinal mucosa and the pancreas, increases lower esophageal sphincter (LES) tone, and is a weak stimulus for the secretion of pancreatic enzymes and bicarbonate. Motilin is produced in the M and enterochromaffin cells of the duodenum and jejunum. Secretion occurs during fasting. Motilin acts to regulate the migrating myoelectric complex (MMC). Secretin is synthesized and stored in the S cells of the mucosa of the upper intestine. Acidification of the duodenal mucosa and the presence of fat and protein degradation products in the duodenum stimulate its secretion. The main role of secretin is to stimulate bicarbonate secretion from the pancreas and liver.
